abstract.text: Evaluation of the radio-transmission pH-measurement system for monitoring the ruminal pH and subacute ruminal acidosis (SARA) in cattle is described.
This is done in order to reveal the possible application of this system for detection and pathophysiological research of SARA by continuous ruminal pH measurement.

The possibility of using this system for assessment of the ruminal pH in SARA cattle, and the presence of negative correlation between the ruminal pH and ruminal temperature in heathy and SARA cattle were determined.

In addition, the 16S rRNA gene pyrosequencing analysis showed that the ruminal microbial community was simpler in SARA cattle, and the bacterial numbers in SARA cattle were lower than those in healthy hay-fed cattle.
Concentrate feeding might have reduced the diversity of the ruminal microbial community.
Changes in the ruminal microbial community of SARA cattle might be related to the changes in ruminal pH followed by the decrease in the number of some bacteria.

Continuous monitoring of the ruminal pH using the radio-transmission pH-measurement system would be applied for detection and prevention of SARA in the field and pathophysiological research of SARA, including ruminal zymology and bacteriology, which have been determined previously by sampling of the ruminal fluid and measuring of ruminal pH.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION

Cows with subacute ruminal acidosis (SARA) often develop complications of laminitis, reduced and erratic feed intake, low body condition score, low milk fat syndrome, abomasal displacement, ulceration and ruminitis (Enemark 2008;Plaizier et al. 2009).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Furthermore, SARA is associated with immunosuppression (Kleen et al. 2003) and inflammation (Khafipour et al. 2009a(Khafipour et al. ,2009bPlaizier et al. 2009).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Free lipopolysaccharide (LPS) increases in the rumen during SARA (Gozho et al. 2007;Emmanuel et al. 2008), and the LPS translocates from the rumen into blood circulation, which activates an inflammatory response (Khafipour et al. 2009a(Khafipour et al. ,2009b affecting peripheral leukocyte populations and production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Therefore, monitoring ruminal pH and prevention of acidic pH are very important challenges in the dairy industry.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: SARA is characterized by repeated bouts of low ruminal pH (Enemark et al. 2004;Enemark 2008;Plaizier et al. 2009), but accurate measurement of the ruminal pH is very difficult.

body_text.text: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

The radio-transmission pH-measurement system consists of a wireless pH sensor, a data measurement receiver, a relay unit and a personal computer with special software (YCOW-S; DKK-Toa Yamagata) (Sato et al. 2012b) installed.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: The wireless system utilized a specified low-power radio transmission system (429 MHz band), which could be operated without a license in accordance with Japanese Radio Law.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: The mean variations of the measurements by the glass pH electrode were + 0.20 after 2 months of continuous recording, compared to the values confirmed by a standard pH solution at the start of the recording.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: The mean lifetime of the internal battery was 3 months when measurements were continuously transmitted every 10 min.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: There was a good correlation between continuous recording and spot sampling (r = 0.986, P < 0.01), when the ruminal pH recorded by our new system was compared to that of the spot sampling of ruminal fluid (Sato et al. 2012b).
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: We have demonstrated the possible application of the radio-transmission pH-measurement system for assessment and monitoring of the ruminal pH in cows.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: Our new system might contribute to accurate assessment and prevention of SARA.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: In this chapter, our experimental results of basic tests for performance of radiotransmission pH-measurement system are described.
body_text.section: CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH BY A RADIO TRANSMISSION MEASUREMENT SYSTEM

body_text.text: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS
The ruminal pH was measured continuously by the radio-transmission pH-measurement system in cattle, which were fed three kinds of diets, 1 week for each.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: Four rumen-cannulated Holstein steers, aged 7 months, were used.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: Cattle were fed orchard grass mixed hay and concentrate (50% flaked barley and 50% corn).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: The ratios of roughage and concentrate were 10:0 (A-diet), 2:8 (B-diet) and 5:5 (C-diet), respectively.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: The pH sensor was placed in the ventral sac of the rumen through rumen-fistula, and pH was measured at 10-min intervals for 4 weeks.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: The ruminal pH decreased markedly and rapidly when feeding changed from A-to B-diet, but it returned to the basal level when feeding changed from B-to C-diet ( Fig. 1).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: Thereafter, another pattern of the ruminal pH changes was observed when B-diet was fed the second time showing moderate decrease in pH compared to that of the first B-diet feeding.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: Within 1 week of B-diet feeding, the decreased ruminal pH recovered slightly.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: In addition, the changes in the ruminal pH after feeding the same diet varied among individual cows.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: These results indicated that the SARA could be induced successfully by feeding the B-diet.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: Changes of the pH values after the morning feeding in this study were similar to previous studies (Krause & Oetzel 2005;Keunen et al. 2002).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: These results demonstrated the possible use of the radio-transmission pHmeasurement system for the assessment and monitoring of ruminal pH of cows in field conditions.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: It is suggested that the ruminal pH could be recoverable after rapid feeding changes by adaptation of ruminal fermentation.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH IN CATTLE FED DIFFERENT DIETS

body_text.text: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID
Ruminal temperature rises during the early phase of disease, estrus and onset of calving (Cooper-Prado et al. 2011; Rose-Dye et al. 2011).
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: In addition, the ruminal temperature exceeds rectal temperature presumably due to accelerated microbial fermentation (AlZahal et al. 2008(AlZahal et al. , 2009.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: Ruminal temperature is negatively correlated with the ruminal pH in cows with SARA, and a predictive equation for aiding the diagnosis of SARA has been sought based on the negative correlation between the lowest ruminal pH and high rumen temperature (AlZahal et al. 2008(AlZahal et al. , 2009.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: However, it is still controversial with regard to whether an accurate ruminal pH can be predicted by measuring ruminal temperature because it is not clear when the lowest pH and the highest temperature appear.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: To assess the relationship between pH and temperature in the ruminal bottom fluid, circadian changes were monitored using cattle fed a control diet (C-diet) or rumen acidosis-inducing (RAI) diet by using the radiotransmission pH-measurement system (Kimura et al. 2012a).
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: Eight primiparous non-lactating, rumencannulated Holstein cattle weighting 620-720 kg were used.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: Both diets were composed of orchard grass and timothy mixed hay and concentrate (equivalent amount of flaked barley and corn).
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: Each cow was given 5.5-6.5 kg twice daily on a dry matter (DM) basis for 2 weeks.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: The ratios of roughage to concentrate for C-diet and RAI-diet were 9:1 and 2:8.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: The pH sensor was placed in the ventral sac of the rumen, and two parameters were measured simultaneously at 10-min intervals for 14 days after commencement of feeding.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: Compared to the mean ruminal pH for 60 min immediately after the morning feeding (0 h), significantly lower pH was noted 3-13 h later (P < 0.05) and 4-19 h later (P < 0.01) in cattle fed C-and RAI-diets, respectively, although the reduction in the latter was much higher than that in the former (Fig. 2).
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: In contrast, significantly higher ruminal temperature was found at 8 and 12 14 h later (P < 0.05) and 6, 8 and 10-19 h later (P < 0.01) in cattle fed C-and RAI-diets, respectively.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: A significant negative correlation was observed between the lowest ruminal pH and its corresponding ruminal temperature in cattle fed C-and RAI-diets (r = -0.722 and -0.650, respectively, P < 0.01), suggesting active fermentation and VFA production in the rumen.
body_text.section: RELATIONS BETWEEN PH AND TEMPERATURE, VFA IN RUMINAL FLUID

body_text.text: However, the ruminal pH profiles may not be predictable by measuring only ruminal temperature because decreases in pH were preceded by increases in temperature, and the circadian changes in pH and temperature were associated with ruminal fermentation.

body_text.text: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

The reliability of ruminal pH depends on the sampling site (bottom vs. middle of the rumen and rumen vs. reticulum) and sampling procedure (rumenocentesis vs. an oro-ruminal probe) (Duffield et al. 2004;Tafaj et al. 2004;Bramley et al. 2008).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: An indwelling wired system has been used to measure pH at the bottom of the rumen (Marden et al. 2005;AlZahal et al. 2007;Penner et al. 2009), but there have been no reports on simultaneous pH measurements of fluids at the bottom and in the middle of the rumen and in the reticulum (i.e. three sites) of cows.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: Furthermore, a few reports had examined the pH of reticulum fluid (Bryant 1964;Lane et al. 1968).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: In these reports the highest pH in the reticulum and the lowest pH at the top or middle of the rumen were reported (Lane et al. 1968).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: To assess the site difference of pH in the rumen and reticulum, circadian pH changes in the fluid of the rumen (bottom and middle) and reticulum were assessed simultaneously using wireless and wired radio-transmission pH-measurement systems in cattle fed the control diet (C-diet) or the RAI diet (Kimura et al. 2012b;Sato et al. 2012c).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: Cattle (n = 8) and diets (C-diet and RAI-diet) used in this study were the same as a previous study, which investigated the relation between ruminal pH and temperature.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: Wireless pH sensor was placed in the ventral sac at the bottom of the rumen and in the reticulum.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: Wired pH sensor was fixed 10-20 cm below the ruminal mat surface (middle of the rumen) by a stout wire through a rumen cannula.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: The pH in the three sites decreased following the morning and evening feedings (Fig. 3).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: In cattle fed the C-diet, the bottom-rumen and reticular pH reverted to the basal level by the next morning, while the middlerumen pH did not recover completely, suggesting that active fermentation occurred in the middle of the rumen.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: The mean pH at 1-h intervals was higher in the reticulum than at the bottom and in the middle of the rumen.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: The relatively stable reticular pH may result from dilution due to salivation and drinking water, as previously described (Dado & Allen 1993).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: In cows fed the RAI-diet, the bottom-rumen pH fell to approximately 5.2 after the evening feeding, but returned to the basal level by the next morning.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: In contrast, the middle-rumen pH did not return to the basal level (6.5) within 24 h, presumably owing to continuous and vigorous fermentation.
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: Significant (P < 0.01) positive correlations were observed in the pH of cattle fed the RAI-diet between in the middle and at the bottom of the rumen (r = 0.894), in the middle of the rumen and in the reticulum (r = 0.764) and at the bottom of the rumen and in the reticulum (r = 0.797).
body_text.section: SIMULTANEOUS ESTIMATION OF PH IN THE RUMEN AND RETICULUM

body_text.text: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

SARA is characterized by ruminal pH (Enemark 2008;Plaizier et al. 2009) lower than 5.6, and pH 5.8 is considered as the marginal threshold for SARA (Kleen et al. 2003;Gozho et al. 2005Gozho et al. , 2007.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: In an experiment of successive SARA induction, decreased ruminal pH was much severer in the day of challenge feeding (Dohme et al. 2008).
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Increased severity of SARA might have been induced by instability of the ruminal microflora (Nagaraja & Titgemeyer 2007), and decreased absorptive capacity of the ruminal epithelium might also have contributed to VFA accumulation in the rumen.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: A short-term, severe insult of acute acidosis decreased ruminal VFA absorption, presumably caused by damage to the ruminal wall (Krehbiel et al. 1995).
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Decreased ruminal absorptive capacity as a result of acidosis challenge may increase the severity of subsequent acidosis challenges.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: However, changes in the ruminal pH and VFA of cattle with repeated acidosis challenges are unknown.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: In addition, molecular techniques have shown that the ruminal microbial community is highly diverse (Mao et al. 2013), but the factors influencing its composition remain unknown.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: The ruminal microbial community in SARA cows has been reported (Chen et al. 2012;Hernandez-Sanabria et al. 2012;Golder et al. 2014), but the relationship between the ruminal pH, VFA and microbiota composition in SARA cattle is unclear.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Bacteria-based probiotics are known to have positive implications on animal health and performance.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Bacterial probiotics have been shown to improve the rumenpredominant microorganisms (Ghorbani et al. 2002;Chiquette et al. 2012;Qadis et al. 2014a) and ruminal performance in cattle (Qadis et al. 2014b,c).
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Steers that received probiotics containing both lactate-utilizing Propionibacterium and lactate-producing Enterococcus had higher ruminal concentrations of acetate, and the blood variables indicated a reduced risk of metabolic acidosis (Ghorbani et al. 2002).
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: However, little information is available about the effect of probiotics containing Propionibacterium on ruminal pH and VFA in cattle.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: Changes in the ruminal pH, VFA and microbial community in cattle with repeatedly induced SARA and effects of Propionibacterium-based probiotics on the ruminal pH and VFA in SARA cattle should be assessed pathophysiologically for the possible association with SARA by continuous monitoring of ruminal pH.
body_text.section: PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF SARA BY CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF RUMINAL PH

body_text.text: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA
The ruminal pH, VFA and microbial composition in cattle with repeatedly induced SARA were investigated to reveal the ruminal adaptation to acute and short-term changes in feeding.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The 16S rRNA gene pyrosequencing and real-time PCR were used to analyze the ruminal microbial community in SARA cattle, and to compare the composition of microbial community in cattle fed hay or high-concentrate diet.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Eight rumen-cannulated Holstein steers (age, 8-10 months; body weight, 180-200 kg) were used and fed hay or RAI diet (20% hay and 80% concentrate) each for 7 days.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Each steer was fed either hay or the RAI-diet for 7 days, 2-3 kg of feed twice daily on a DM basis, followed by the other diet for an additional 7 days without a resting period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: This experiment was continuously performed twice.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The pH sensor was placed in the ventral sac of the rumen and pH was measured every 10 min.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Ruminal fluid was collected three times (08.00, 14.00 and 20.00 hours) at 7 days after starting each feeding period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Total VFA and VFA components were separated and quantified by gas chromatography.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The microbial community of the ruminal fluids was analyzed by 16S rRNA arrangement analysis (four of eight cattle in the first experimental period) and real time PCR (four of eight cattle in both experimental periods) using bacterial DNA extraction from fluids collected at 20.00 hours.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The 24-h mean ruminal pH values in the concentratefed (CF) period were significantly (P < 0.05) lower than those in the hay-fed (FF) period, and the pH values obtained at 3 days after concentrate feeding were slightly lower in the first experiment compared to the second experiment (Fig. 4).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The 1-h mean pH values of the ruminal fluids decreased gradually following morning and evening feedings in both FF and CF periods, and the pH values in the CF period were lower overall than those in the FF period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Ruminal total VFA, propionic acid and butyric acid concentrations, and LPS activity in the CF period were slightly higher than those in the FF period (Fig. 5).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: However, no significant difference was observed in the ruminal total VFA, concentration of each VFA and lactic acid, as well as LPS activity between the first and second experiments.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The 16S rRNA gene pyrosequencing analysis showed that the ruminal microbial community was simpler in the CF period than in the FF period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Detected numbers of the bacterial phylum, genus and species in the CF period were significantly (P < 0.05) lower than those in the FF period (Table 1).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: At the phylum level, Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes and Actinobacteria were dominant in during both FF and CF periods (Fig. 6).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The percentages of Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria were reduced by concentrate feeding, whereas Firmicutes was more abundant in the CF period than the FF period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: At the genus level, Prevotella, Clostridium, Butyrivibrio, Eubacterium and Ruminococcus were dominant in both feeding periods.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: As compared with the FF period, the ratios of Prevotella and Eubacterium were lower, while the percentages of Ruminococcus, Clostridium and Butyrivibrio increased in the CF period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: The real-time PCR analysis showed that the bacterial numbers of total methanogens, Fibrobacter succinogenes and Selenomonas ruminantium, significantly (P < 0.05) decreased, and those of Streptococcus bovis and Megasphaera elsdenii significantly (P < 0.05) increased in the CF period compared to the FF period (Fig. 7).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: In the FF period, the bacterial numbers of total bacteria, total methanogens and Selenomonas ruminantium in the second experimental period were significantly (P < 0.05) lower than those in the first experiment.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: In the CF period, both ruminal pH and bacterial diversity were lower and the rumen microbial composition was simpler than those in the FF period.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Concentrate feeding might have reduced the diversity of the rumen microbial community.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Changes in the rumen microbial  composition of SARA cattle might be related to the marked changes in ruminal pH followed by the rapid decrease in numbers of bacteria.
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: Changes in ruminal pH and rumen microbial community were observed markedly by acute and short-term change in feeding, which indicated ruminal adaptation (Mao et al. 2013).
body_text.section: CHANGES IN RUMINAL PH, VFA AND MICROBIOTA COMPOSITION IN CATTLE WITH REPEATEDLY INDUCED SARA

body_text.text: However, further research is needed to reveal the relation between ruminal pH and microbial community.

body_text.text: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE
Propionibacteria are natural inhabitants of the rumen and they produce propionate, a major precursor for glucose production, through hepatic gluconeogenesis (Sauer et al. 1989).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: increase hepatic glucose production and positively influence host metabolism (Francisco et al. 2002).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: The effects of propionibacteria feeding on the lactational performance of dairy cows in early lactation have been reported (Stein et al. 2006;Lehloenya et al. 2008;Weiss et al. 2008), and the cattle that received probiotics containing lactate-utilizing Propionibacterium had higher ruminal concentrations of acetate (Ghorbani et al. 2002).
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: However, little information is available regarding the effect of probiotics containing Propionibacterium on the ruminal pH and VFA in cattle.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: To evaluate the preventive effect of Propionibacterium on ruminal pH and SARA, changes in the ruminal pH and VFA of cattle administered Propionibacterium-based probiotic were investigated.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: Four primiparous non-lactating, rumen-cannulated Holstein cattle weighing 620-700 kg were used, and the experiment was performed three times at 4-week intervals.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: Cattle were fed hay over the 2 weeks before the experiment.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: Thereafter, the RAI-diet consisting of 20% hay and 80% concentrate was fed for 2 weeks.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: Each cow was given 6-7 kg feed twice daily on a DM basis.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: During the RAI-died feeding, two groups of cattle were fed simultaneously either with a Propionibacterium-based probiotic (5×10 10 colony forming units) (A-diet), or with a Propionibacterium-based probiotic plus fermented products of Lactobacillus (10 g) and lactose (23.5 g) (B-diet) once a day.
body_text.section: EFFECTS OF PROPIONIBACTERIUM-BASED PROBIOTIC ON RUMINAL PH AND VFA IN CATTLE

body_text.text: Cattle fed the RAI-diet without probiotic served as the control.

body_text.text: The ruminal pH was measured at 10-min intervals using the pH sensor, and the ruminal fluids for VFA analysis were collected at 14 days after RAI-diet feeding.

body_text.text: Conclusion

Continuous monitoring of the ruminal pH using a newly invented radio-transmission pH-measurement system could be applied for detection and prevention of SARA in the field and pathophysiological research of SARA, including the ruminal zymology and bacteriology, which have been determined previously by sampling of the ruminal fluid and measuring of ruminal pH.
